1.question: What is the primary method used to achieve strain engineering in traditional semiconductors?

options.A: Growth on lattice-mismatched substrates
options.B: Mechanical bending
options.C: Thermal expansion coefficient mismatch
options.D: Epitaxial growth

2.question: Why is the traditional method of strain engineering not applicable to 2D materials?

options.A: Due to the weak interaction between 2D materials and substrates
options.B: Due to the strong interaction between 2D materials and substrates
options.C: Due to the lattice mismatch between 2D materials and substrates
options.D: Due to the thermal expansion coefficient mismatch between 2D materials and substrates
options.E: Due to the epitaxial growth of 2D materials

3.question: What is the method used to achieve strain engineering in 2D materials in this study?

options.A: Growth on lattice-mismatched substrates
options.B: Mechanical bending
options.C: Thermal expansion coefficient mismatch
options.D: Epitaxial growth

options.A: MoS2
options.B: WSe2
options.C: Graphene
options.D: Silicon

5.question: What is the range of strains achieved in this study?

options.A: 1% compressive to 0.2% tensile
options.B: 1% tensile to 0.2% compressive
options.C: 0.1% tensile to 0.1% compressive
options.D: 10% tensile to 10% compressive

options.A: It increases the bandgap
options.B: It decreases the bandgap
options.C: It causes an indirect-to-direct bandgap transition
options.D: It causes a direct-to-indirect bandgap transition
options.E: It has no effect on the bandgap

options.B: It increases the photoluminescence intensity
options.C: It has no effect on the photoluminescence intensity
options.D: It causes a redshift in the photoluminescence peak
options.E: It causes a blueshift in the photoluminescence peak
